Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from four fragments) of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: glazed black with reserved band below junction of rim and body; exterior: wide black band at top of rim with trace of single added red band; lower part of rim and handle zone reserved with line between; two lines and glazed area below handle zone; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B3
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer identifies the sherd as coming from a Type 9C South Ionian cup with everted rim despite the unusually glazed rim. Type 9C cups correspond to Attic Siana or Gordion cups and find parallels with Hayes' Ionian Cup Type X (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-6) and Vallet and Villard's Ionian Cup type B3 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-8). The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Type 5 cups are rare at Naukratis whereas there are numerous examples of Type 9 cups. Both types were common drinking vessels found in Greeks sanctuaries, including the sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus. The sherd is from the same cup as British Museum 1888,0601.251, and almost certainly 1965,0930.691 and 692 (the latter noted by Gardner 1888).
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 52, no. 266, p. 109-10 NAU 67, pl. 14 e-g)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.728) (Phase 3)
